p: Many possible therapies have been pre-clinically and clinically tested against the disease, and many more are in process; however, only a few were found to be effective. Chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine both show a similar mode of action by acting as a weak base that can increase the pH of endosomes preventing virus/cell fusion ( Yao et al., 2020). Both were found to be active in vitro and also successfully eliminated nasopharyngeal carriage of SARS-COV-2 in patients infected with COVID-19. However, recent data from large randomized controlled trials showed no evidence of benefit for viral clearance, mortality or other outcomes of chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine treatment over standard care in hospitalized patients with COVID-19 ( Tang et al., 2020). Lopinavir, a highly-specific HIV-1 protease inhibitor, appears to block the critical protease (Mpro) of SARS-CoV, which inhibits the replication of the virus ( Ratia et al., 2008). It was found that 4 mg/ml of lopinavir and 50 mg/ml of ribavirin inhibited SARS-CoV after incubation of 48 h and the agents when combined act synergistically ( Chu et al., 2004). However, no benefit has been observed beyond standard care with lopinavir-ritonavir treatment in hospitalized adult patients suffering from extreme COVID-19 ( Cao et al., 2020).
